text: Yeah, if the package's version is less than 1.0, then bumping the Julia compat entry only requires a patch bump

elements.text: Yeah, if the package's version is less than 1.0, then bumping the Julia compat entry only requires a patch bump

text: My understanding is that is true, except when updating the julia version min

text: For updating packages patches are fine if you're packe version is less than 1

text: I’ve had this argument a few times, and I think by the book you are supposed to make it a breaking change if you drop a Julia version.

elements.text: I’ve had this argument a few times, and I think by the book you are supposed to make it a breaking change if you drop a Julia version.

text: The logic being that, if you do need to release a patch for 1.0, there are still version numbers available for that.

elements.text: The logic being that, if you do need to release a patch for 1.0, there are still version numbers available for that.

text: Things just get tricky when you force yourself to work with just 2 numbers instead of 3.

elements.text: Things just get tricky when you force yourself to work with just 2 numbers instead of 3.

text: Yeah the correct answer here is that people should have package version numbers that are >= 1.0

elements.text: Yeah the correct answer here is that people should have package version numbers that are >= 1.0

text: So then you can bump the minor version number when you drop support for an old Julia version

elements.text: So then you can bump the minor version number when you drop support for an old Julia version

text: For packages that are < 1.0, if you bump the minor version number, then all downstream dependencies now need to update their compat entries. Which leads to a lot of code churn in the ecosystem. And since dropping support for a Julia version really isn't a breaking change to a public API, it's not really consistent with SemVer

elements.text: For packages that are < 1.0, if you bump the minor version number, then all downstream dependencies now need to update their compat entries. Which leads to a lot of code churn in the ecosystem. And since dropping support for a Julia version really isn't a breaking change to a public API, it's not really consistent with SemVer

text: Yes. Sadly going to 1.0 also induces churn. Would be neat if the package could declare “0.5 == 1.0” somehow, to make that step non-breaking… although no doubt that would have a lot of other weird sharp edges

elements.text: Yes. Sadly going to 1.0 also induces churn. Would be neat if the package could declare “0.5 == 1.0” somehow, to make that step non-breaking… although no doubt that would have a lot of other weird sharp edges

text: I think we just should make a 1.0 Matlab.jl release..
